evidence.text: This action arises under the APA, 5 U.S.C. §701 et seq.;
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Administrative Procedure Act (APA)

evidence.text: This action arises under the APA, 5 U.S.C. §701 et seq.; the Public Health Service Act (PHSA), 42 U.S.C. §201 et seq.;
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Public Health Service Act (PHSA)

evidence.text: Section 301 of the PHSA, 42 U.S.C. §241, contains Congress’s overarching authorization for NIH
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Section 405 of the PHSA, 42 U.S.C. §284, imposes similar responsibilities and confers similar authority
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Congress has provided that the NIH director “shall, in conducting and supporting programs for research, research training, recruitment, and other activities, provide for an increase in the number of women and individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds...” 42 U.S.C. §282(h).
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Congress has provided that the NIH director shall “encourage efforts to improve research related to the health of sexual and gender minority populations...” 42 U.S.C. §283p.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Congress has instructed the National Cancer Institute to “expand, intensify, and coordinate the activities of the Institute with respect to research on breast... cancers of the reproductive system of women.” 42 U.S.C. §285a-6.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Congress has required the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute to conduct research into the prevalence of certain heart conditions in women, “including African-American women and other women who are members of racial or ethnic minority groups.” 42 U.S.C. §285b-7a(c)(1)
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Congress has established a National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities to support research and training “with respect to minority health conditions and other populations with health disparities.” 42 U.S.C. §285t(a).
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Congress has established an Office of Research on Women’s Health within NIH to “determine the extent to which women are represented among senior physicians and scientists...” 42 U.S.C. §287d(e).
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Congress has instructed the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award Ruth L. Kirschstein National Research Service Awards “in a manner that will result in the recruitment of women, and individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds...” 42 U.S.C. §288(a)(4).
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Plaintiffs seek relief from this Court. The Court should order NIH to undertake the grant-application review process as the law requires.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Order NIH to undertake grant-application review process as required by law

evidence.text: And it should set aside the NIH’s unlawful termination of plaintiffs’ already-issued grants.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Set aside unlawful termination of plaintiffs' already-issued grants

evidence.text: Judge Brian E. Murphy assigned to case.

evidence.text: United States Court of Appeals For the First Circuit

COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS; STATE OF CALIFORNIA; ... Plaintiffs, Appellees, v. ROBERT F. KENNEDY, JR., in his official capacity as Secretary of the United States Department of Health and Human Services; ... Defendants, Appellants.
APPEAL FROM THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF MASSACHUSETTS

add_extracted.value: Appeal: Defendants (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, National Institutes of Health, etc.) appealed to United States Court of Appeals For the First Circuit

evidence.text: See Am. Pub. Health Ass'n v. NIH, Nos. 25-cv-10787, 25-cv-10814, 2025 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 125988, at *9-10 (D. Mass. July 2, 2025).

add_extracted.value: Am. Pub. Health Ass'n v. NIH, 2025 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 125988 (D. Mass. July 2, 2025)

add_extracted.value: July 2, 2025: Entry of decree declaring Challenged Directives unlawful under APA

event.doc_name: Time Sensistive Motion for Stay Pending Appeal and Immediate Administrative Stay

evidence.text: The district court informally consolidated the two cases by holding a combined merits hearing.
evidence.source_document: Time Sensistive Motion for Stay Pending Appeal and Immediate Administrative Stay

add_extracted.value: Cases consolidated: APHA Case (25-cv-10787) and States Case (25-cv-10814)

evidence.text: On February 10, 2025, the Acting Secretary of Health and Human Services directed agency personnel to 'ensure that taxpayer dollars are used to advance the best interest of the government. This includes avoiding the expenditure of federal funds on programs... that promote or take part in diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives or any other initiatives that discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, or another perceived characteristic.'
evidence.source_document: Time Sensistive Motion for Stay Pending Appeal and Immediate Administrative Stay

add_extracted.value: Grant terminations by NIH and ICs due to non-compliance with agency priorities related to DEI, gender identity, and vaccine hesitancy research; plaintiffs challenged these terminations under APA and constitutional claims.

evidence.text: the district court issued partial final judgments under Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b) in both cases that: (1) the 'Challenged Directives as a whole are arbitrary and capricious... and are hereby vacated and set aside,' and (2) the grant terminations are 'arbitrary and capricious... and are hereby vacated and set aside.'
evidence.source_document: Time Sensistive Motion for Stay Pending Appeal and Immediate Administrative Stay

add_extracted.value: Vacated Challenged Directives (including guidance on DEI, gender identity, and vaccine hesitancy) and vacated grant terminations.

evidence.text: the district court informally consolidated the two cases by holding a combined merits hearing. At the hearing’s conclusion, the court made oral findings and rulings, promising that a 'full written opinion' would follow.
evidence.source_document: Time Sensistive Motion for Stay Pending Appeal and Immediate Administrative Stay

add_extracted.value: Combined merits hearing held on June 16, 2025, with oral findings and rulings; bench trial.

evidence.text: the district court issued partial final judgments under Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b) in both cases... The orders also contained a list of the grant terminations that were being reversed.
evidence.source_document: Time Sensistive Motion for Stay Pending Appeal and Immediate Administrative Stay

add_extracted.value: Partial final judgment vacating Challenged Directives and grant terminations under Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b), entered July 2, 2025.

evidence.text: the district court issued partial final judgments under Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b) in both cases that: (1) the 'Challenged Directives as a whole are arbitrary and capricious... and are hereby vacated and set aside.'
evidence.source_document: Time Sensistive Motion for Stay Pending Appeal and Immediate Administrative Stay
